title: Blackbody - rank diameters of stars 1 2 and 3

content.question: StarAbsolute Temperature of SurfaceRadiated Power<math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math><math alttext="T sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math><math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math><math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math><math alttext="2 T sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math><math alttext="2 P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math><math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math><math alttext="2 T sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math><math alttext="16 P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>Three stars, Star <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, Star <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and Star <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> can be modeled as spherical blackbodies. The surface temperatures and total power radiated by the stars are listed in the table. Which of the following correctly ranks the diameters <math alttext="d sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="d sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="d sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> of stars <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, respectively?

choices.label: <math alttext="d sub 1 equals, d sub 3, which is greater than d sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="d sub 2 equals, d sub 3, which is greater than d sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="d sub 3 is greater than, d sub 1, which equals d sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="d sub 3 is greater than, d sub 2, which is greater than d sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="d sub 1 equals, d sub 3, which is greater than d sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
